thread.title: Veteran skateboarder Tony Hawk hits Sydney for BowlARama
thread.title_full: Veteran skateboarder Tony Hawk hits Sydney for BowlARama

title: Veteran skateboarder Tony Hawk hits Sydney for BowlARama
text:
The American is in Sydney for Bowl-A-Rama — a series of skateboarding contests for professional men, women, juniors and masters. 
He won the masters category last year and said he was looking forward to defending his title. 
"I'm trying to mix up my routines a little bit," Hawk said. 
"I don't want to come here and just sort of play the oldies, I want to know that I'm progressing a little bit so I've been trying something a little different with my lines." 
At the competition launch event in Bondi today, Hawk said at his age skateboarding was all about stamina. 
"The thing I notice is my endurance, it's hard to keep up and I really have to work at it — I took that for granted when I was younger," he said. 
"For the most part when I was in my 20s, [I would] go out all night, go to the event the next day and make it work. 
"But now it's like if you're going to do this for a living at my age, you have got to take it pretty seriously, not train for it, but you've got to take care of your body." 
Hawk turned professional 34 years ago at the age of 14 and travelled the world winning skateboarding competitions. 
He was so successful he earned enough money to buy his first home before he finished high school. Hawk created video game to lure fans back 
The sport lost fans in the 1990s, but Hawk turned his attention to creating a skateboarding video game in an effort to lure them back. 
The first Tony Hawk's Pro Skater was released in 1999, and there are now 10 titles in the series. Photo: Skateboarders Poppy Olsen and Tony Hawk are looking forward to the weekend competition in Bondi. (ABC News: Dylan Clunes) 
He carried on competing and is still considered a legend in the skateboarding world. 
Last year he managed to land his signature trick — a 900-degree aerial spin, commonly referred to as "the 900". 
It was 17 years to the day since he landed his first one at the X Games in San Francisco. 
At the time he said: "I never thought I'd be doing this at this age, [but] I'm still going — I'll keep going until the wheels fall off, I guess." 
This Sunday he will compete against fellow skateboarding veterans, Steve Caballero and Mike McGill, who are both in their early 50s. Big crowds expected for professional competitions Photo: A winning skateboard design from a fan and chosen by Tony Hawk. (ABC News: Dylan Clunes) 
The professional men's, women's and junior competitions are also expected to draw big crowds. 
Poppy Olsen, 16, from Newcastle is looking forward to taking on 12 female competitors from all over the world and hopes to raise the profile of girls' skateboarding. Photo: A Tony Hawk fan with his personally signed skateboard. (ABC News: Dylan Clunes) 
"I was the only girl skater at my local park for about a year and now there are lots of local girl skateboarders, you're seeing new faces pop up everywhere," she said. 
"It's really fun just having more competitors — we all push ourselves and it's just a really supportive sport, so it's really fun competing with all the girls." 
Ethan Copeland, 11, is one of the youngest competitors in the Bowl-A-Rama event. 
"It's really awesome to know that you're skating with the best in the world and they're supporting a local competition," Ethan said. 
"I'm really hoping to get a 540 which is where you spin 540 degrees." 
Skateboarding will be included at the next Summer Olympic Games in Tokyo in 2020, as part of an attempt by the International Olympic Committee to bring the games to young people. 
"The most exciting part of the Olympics for me is you'll see skate teams form the most unlikely countries — Cambodia, Ethiopia, Afghanistan," Hawk said. 
"There are strong skate teams in those countries that no one knows really about and they're going to be at a world venue and that's incredible to me."
